WRR103H1-F-20219.courseDescription: A course on essay writing designed to equip students with the skills required to write on different subjects and in a variety of different genres (including critical analysis, the narrative essay, and argumentative writing). By unpacking the stages of the writing process, this course helps students develop research, critical reading, planning, organization, writing, editing, and proofreading skills.

WRR103H1-S-20219.courseDescription: A course on essay writing designed to equip students with the skills required to write on different subjects and in a variety of different genres (including critical analysis, the narrative essay, and argumentative writing). By unpacking the stages of the writing process, this course helps students develop research, critical reading, planning, organization, writing, editing, and proofreading skills.
WRR103H1-S-20219.webTimetableInstructions: LEC2000 and LEC2001 are restricted to students in the Transitional Year Programme and do not have tutorials.

WRR104H1-S-20219.courseDescription: An examination into the practical and theoretical aspects of writing reports. This writing intensive course introduces the fundamentals of report writing within an interdisciplinary context and focuses on improving writing skills appropriate to report writing genres. This course provides students the opportunity to prepare abstracts, literature reviews, qualitative and quantitative research, a formal report and a poster presentation at the end of the term. Focus will be on purpose, audience, structure, style, persuasive strategies and visual rhetoric (tables, charts, graphs) and research methods.

WRR201H1-F-20219.courseTitle: Theories of Rhetoric: A Brief History of Persuasion
WRR201H1-F-20219.courseDescription: The history of rhetoric, the philosophical art of persuasion, is a complex one bound up with the histories of philosophy, literature, and religion, the rise and fall of empires, and the emergence of modern science and media technology. We will examine the development of rhetoric over time, from the roots of the discipline in classical antiquity to the genesis of modern and postmodern rhetoric, including the New Rhetoric. We will then focus on contemporary rhetorical currents in language philosophy, gender studies, critical race studies, and affect theory.

WRR203H1-F-20219.courseDescription: Designed to teach students to write persuasively and to recognize persuasive strategies at work in writing they analyze. Classical rhetorical terms, elements of style, and modes of argument are central to the course. Assignments include a rhetorical analysis, in-class close reading exercises, and a term essay. Readings include prose from a variety of disciplines, excluding fiction and poetry. Students who enrol in the course must demonstrate competence in the English language.

WRR203H1-S-20219.courseDescription: Designed to teach students to write persuasively and to recognize persuasive strategies at work in writing they analyze. Classical rhetorical terms, elements of style, and modes of argument are central to the course. Assignments include a rhetorical analysis, in-class close reading exercises, and a term essay. Readings include prose from a variety of disciplines, excluding fiction and poetry. Students who enrol in the course must demonstrate competence in the English language.

WRR300H1-F-20219.courseTitle: Strategic Writing in Business and the Professions: Theory and Practice
WRR300H1-F-20219.courseDescription: Aims to teach students to recognize the rhetoric of the professional workplace and to communicate strategically and ethically using written and oral discourse appropriate to business, government, and not-for-profit organizations. Case study analysis using ethical reasoning models is a central component of the course.

LEC-9901.meetingStatusNotes: July 7, 2021: Section Number changed, Delivery Method changed.

WRR302H1-F-20219.courseTitle: Writing in Business and the Professions for Rotman Commerce Students
WRR302H1-F-20219.courseDescription: Designed for and restricted to undergraduates in Rotman Commerce. Assignments and course aims reflect the learning goals of the Rotman Commerce program. This course focuses on critical thinking, ethical reasoning, and the rhetoric of the world of business. The theory and practice of written and oral communication are also central. Case study analysis using ethical reasoning models is a central pedagogical tool.

LEC-9901.meetingStatusNotes: July 7, 2021: Section Number changed, Delivery Method changed.

WRR302H1-S-20219.courseTitle: Writing in Business and the Professions for Rotman Commerce Students
WRR302H1-S-20219.courseDescription: Designed for and restricted to undergraduates in Rotman Commerce. Assignments and course aims reflect the learning goals of the Rotman Commerce program. This course focuses on critical thinking, ethical reasoning, and the rhetoric of the world of business. The theory and practice of written and oral communication are also central. Case study analysis using ethical reasoning models is a central pedagogical tool.

WRR303H1-F-20219.courseDescription: Examines the profound impact of digital media on contemporary culture and discourse. Students will explore recent currents in rhetoric and digital media. Students will investigate the rhetorical operation of digital media in domains ranging from academia to politics to popular culture. The class will analyze the role of rhetorical principles, such as persuasion and identification, in a diverse array of online discourse such as discussion forums, social media, and the blogosphere.

WRR303H1-S-20219.courseDescription: Examines the profound impact of digital media on contemporary culture and discourse. Students will explore recent currents in rhetoric and digital media. Students will investigate the rhetorical operation of digital media in domains ranging from academia to politics to popular culture. The class will analyze the role of rhetorical principles, such as persuasion and identification, in a diverse array of online discourse such as discussion forums, social media, and the blogosphere.

WRR305H1-F-20219.courseTitle: Word and Image in Modern Writing
WRR305H1-F-20219.courseDescription: The rhetorical term Ekphrasis, which refers to writing that is about visual art, is central in the examination of the persuasive power of the conversation or discourse that is produced when the written word attempts the evocation of visual images. Course readings will include ekphrastic texts drawn from several disciplines and genres: journalism, informal essays, poetry, and scholarly writing.

WRR308H1-S-20219.courseTitle: Selected Topics in Writing and Rhetoric
WRR308H1-S-20219.courseDescription: Courses on selected topics in Writing and Rhetoric.
WRR308H1-S-20219.webTimetableInstructions: Course Description for Winter 2022: This course brings rhetorical thought into important dialogue with health research and medical practices. Since its inception, rhetoric has been concerned with persuasion and its relationship to human flourishing. With this in mind, contemporary rhetorical scholars have interrogated the role rhetoric plays in matters pertaining to health and wellness.  Medicalized phenomenalike hypochondria, depression, sexual dysfunction, and death & dyingare all bound up with influence. A rhetorical perspective on health and wellness tracks this influence through the networks of individuals, institutions, texts, media forms, genres, narratives, opinions, and identifications that constitute the interpenetrating worlds of health care consumers, medical practitioners, and researchers.

WRR310H1-S-20219.courseDescription: This course introduces students to professional editorial conventions at two later stages of the editorial process. Both stages require analytical skills and sentence expertise. Through stylistic editing, students learn how to improve a writers literary style; through copy editing, they learn how to ensure both accuracy and consistency (editorial style).

WRR311Y1-Y-20219.courseDescription: This workshop course examines methodological approaches to literary fiction from the perspective of the creator. Through course readings, discussion, and creative writing assignments, student writers will learn how prose writers combine stylistic techniques, point-of-view, setting, character, scenes, and structure to produce literary effects.
WRR311Y1-Y-20219.recommendedPreparation: Experience or strong interest in writing fiction.
WRR311Y1-Y-20219.deliveryInstructions: Recordings of lecture will be available for students to view asynchronously. Most class activities will occur synchronously in person at the scheduled course time. Students will not be expected to screen lectures before class. A microphone and webcam are required for every class.

WRR316H1-F-20219.courseDescription: This course introduces professional editorial conventions at two early stages of the editorial process. Both stages require editors to think critically and creatively as they assess content, organization, and argument. Students learn how to analyze and evaluate these elements, envision possible improvements, and explain these suggestions persuasively.

WRR405Y1-Y-20219.courseTitle: Independent Studies in Writing and Rhetoric
WRR405Y1-Y-20219.courseDescription: Independent research projects devised by students and supervised by the Writing and Rhetoric staff. Open only to students who are completing the Minor Program in Writing and Rhetoric Program. Applications should be submitted to the Program Director by June 1 for a Fall session course or by November 1 for a Spring session course. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
WRR405Y1-Y-20219.webTimetableInstructions: For more information, please contact Jannie Chien, Writing and Rhetoric Program Coordinator at programs.innis@utoronto.ca.

WRR406H1-S-20219.courseTitle: Independent Studies in Writing and Rhetoric
WRR406H1-S-20219.courseDescription: Independent research projects devised by students and supervised by the Writing and Rhetoric staff. Open only to students who are completing the Minor Program in Writing and Rhetoric Program. Applications should be submitted to the Program Director by June 1 for a Fall session course or by November 1 for a Spring session course. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
WRR406H1-S-20219.webTimetableInstructions: For more information, please contact Jannie Chien, Writing and Rhetoric Program Coordinator at programs.innis@utoronto.ca.

WRR409H1-F-20219.courseTitle: Special Topics in Writing and Rhetoric
WRR409H1-F-20219.courseDescription: Seminars in special topics designed for students who are completing the Minor Program in Writing and Rhetoric.

WRR413H1-S-20219.courseTitle: Visual Rhetoric of the Aesthetic Movement
WRR413H1-S-20219.courseDescription: Explores the role of writing and rhetoric in the shaping of material culture and public taste in Victorian illustrated magazines and newspapers in the Aesthetic period (1860-1900). The Great Exhibition of 1851 will provide the context for this study of texts and objects, including the decorative arts.

WRR414H1-S-20219.courseDescription: We will read and write a variety of texts focused on effecting social change. Students will be encouraged to engage with different theories of social change and an array of writing genres, ranging from journalism to critical theory to fiction. Ultimately, students will focus on one or several key social issues that they wish to write about for their final project.
